Main article: [2017 Wimbledon
Championships](/wiki/2017_Wimbledon_Championships "2017 Wimbledon
Championships")

[Serena Williams](/wiki/Serena_Williams "Serena Williams") was the two-time
defending champion, but did not defend her title because of
[pregnancy](/wiki/Serena_Williams#2017:_Australian_Open_victory_and_pregnancy
"Serena Williams").[1]

[Garbiñe Muguruza](/wiki/Garbi%C3%B1e_Muguruza "Garbiñe Muguruza") won her
second Grand Slam singles title, defeating [Venus
Williams](/wiki/Venus_Williams "Venus Williams") in the final, 7–5, 6–0.[2]
Muguruza became the second Spanish woman to win Wimbledon after [Conchita
Martínez](/wiki/Conchita_Mart%C3%ADnez "Conchita Martínez") in
[1994](/wiki/1994_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles "1994
Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles").[3] Muguruza also became the first
player to defeat both [Williams sisters](/wiki/Williams_sisters "Williams
sisters") in Grand Slams singles finals.[4]

Williams was the oldest player to reach the final since [Martina
Navratilova](/wiki/Martina_Navratilova "Martina Navratilova"), also in 1994,
and played her 100th singles match at Wimbledon when she defeated [Jeļena
Ostapenko](/wiki/Je%C4%BCena_Ostapenko "Jeļena Ostapenko") in the
quarterfinals.[5][6] [Johanna Konta](/wiki/Johanna_Konta "Johanna Konta")
became the first British woman to reach the semifinals since [Virginia
Wade](/wiki/Virginia_Wade "Virginia Wade") in
[1978](/wiki/1978_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles "1978
Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles"),[7] and [Magdaléna
Rybáriková](/wiki/Magdal%C3%A9na_Ryb%C3%A1rikov%C3%A1 "Magdaléna Rybáriková")
became the first Slovak woman to reach the semifinals at Wimbledon.[8]

Despite losing in the second round, [Karolína
Plíšková](/wiki/Karol%C3%ADna_Pl%C3%AD%C5%A1kov%C3%A1 "Karolína Plíšková")
attained the [WTA No. 1 singles
ranking](/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_tennis_players#Singles "List of WTA
number 1 ranked tennis players") at the end of the tournament, after
[Angelique Kerber](/wiki/Angelique_Kerber "Angelique Kerber") and [Simona
Halep](/wiki/Simona_Halep "Simona Halep"), the other contenders for the top
ranking, lost in the fourth round and quarterfinals, respectively.[9]
